questions.question: What was the Enlightenment?
choices: A time of new ideas about politics, philosophy, and science
questions.explanation: The Enlightenment was a period in the 18th century focused on new ideas in politics, philosophy, and science.

questions.question: Which century did the Enlightenment take place?
questions.explanation: The Enlightenment occurred during the 18th century.

questions.question: Which country produced many great Enlightenment thinkers?
questions.explanation: Many key Enlightenment thinkers, such as Adam Smith and David Hume, were Scottish.

questions.question: Who developed ideas about economics during the Enlightenment?
questions.explanation: Adam Smith developed influential ideas about economics still used today.

questions.question: Whose ideas about human nature influenced philosophers?
questions.explanation: David Hume’s ideas about human nature continue to influence philosophy.

questions.question: Who worked on steam power that helped the Industrial Revolution?
questions.explanation: James Watt’s work on steam power supported the development of the Industrial Revolution.

questions.question: What key belief came from the Enlightenment?
choices: Everyone should obey the state’s religion
The king should rule without question
People should have freedom of political and religious beliefs
questions.explanation: The Enlightenment promoted freedom of thought, religion, and politics.

questions.question: Before the Industrial Revolution, what was the main source of employment in Britain?
questions.explanation: Before industrialisation, most British people worked in agriculture.

questions.question: When did the Industrial Revolution occur?
questions.explanation: The Industrial Revolution took place during the 18th and 19th centuries.

questions.question: Which process allowed the mass production of steel?
questions.explanation: The Bessemer process enabled mass production of steel, helping shipbuilding and railways.

questions.question: What was built to connect factories and ports?
questions.explanation: Canals were built to transport raw materials and goods between factories, cities, and ports.

questions.question: Who mapped the coast of Australia?
questions.explanation: Captain James Cook mapped the coast of Australia during British colonisation.

questions.question: Which company gained control of large parts of India?
questions.explanation: The East India Company gained control of large areas in India.

questions.question: Where did Britain get sugar and tobacco from?
choices: North America and the West Indies
questions.explanation: Britain imported sugar and tobacco from North America and the West Indies.

questions.question: Who improved the carding machine in textile production?
questions.explanation: Richard Arkwright improved the carding machine, making textile production more efficient.

questions.question: What was the name of the first curry house in Britain?
questions.explanation: Sake Dean Mahomet opened the Hindoostane Coffee House in London in 1810.

questions.question: What art did Sake Dean Mahomet introduce to Britain?
questions.explanation: Sake Dean Mahomet introduced 'shampooing', the Indian art of head massage, to Britain.

questions.question: From where were most slaves taken during the slave trade?
questions.explanation: Most slaves were taken from West Africa to the Americas and Caribbean.

questions.question: Who led the movement to abolish slavery in Britain?
questions.explanation: William Wilberforce, an MP and Christian, led the abolitionist campaign against slavery.

questions.question: In which year did the Emancipation Act abolish slavery in the British Empire?
questions.explanation: The Emancipation Act of 1833 ended slavery throughout the British Empire.

questions.question: Which group first campaigned against slavery in Britain?
questions.explanation: The Quakers were the first to form anti-slavery groups and petition Parliament.
